title: REGIONAL SOURCING
text: Most building materials, components, and labor were sourced from the region.

title: LABOR AND CRAFT
text: As many as 500 construction workers labored simultaneously on site at the height of construction activity, while hundreds more were involved in the extended network of manufacturing and supply.

title: GHOST BUILDINGS
text: A dozen buildings were cleared to make way for the new residential colleges, including the former Mudd Library, pictured here (Roth and Moore, 1982, Yale Visual Resources Collection).

title: GEOTHERMAL
text: Geothermal wells extend 500 feet beneath the courtyards, providing a portion of the energy for the heating-cooling system.

title: TOWER
text: The crown of the 192-foot-tall tower was constructed using a system of ornamental panels affixed to a steel frame. (Robert A.M. Stern Architects.)

title: STRUCTURE
text: Beneath the Collegiate Gothic facade lies a modern structural frame of reinforced concrete.

title: PROSPECT STREET
text: Electric trolleys traveled along Prospect Street in the early 20th century; recent improvements include a bike lane and new lighting.

title: GATES
text: Eight hand-forged iron gates, each with a unique design, continue a metalcraft tradition.

title: COURTYARDS
text: Courtyards are key to Yale’s residential colleges and their relationship to the city.

title: WINDOWS
text: A layer of leaded, color-tinted art glass supplements the thermally efficient, insulated glass units.

title: FACE BRICK
text: Over a million hand-placed bricks in a three colors, manufactured in Pennsylvania, clad Franklin and Murray Colleges.

title: CHIMNEYS
text: The 45 chimneys of Franklin and Murray Colleges include 19 different designs, many of which serve air handling functions.

title: GREENWAY
text: The Farmington Canal (1828-1847) became a railroad in 1848 and in recent years a cycling and pedestrian paths. (Connecticut Historical Society)
